data.name: HTTP as Exfil
data.description: The attackers use HTTP as an exfil method. This is usually used in conjunction with some type of stego. For example, VSAgent uses base64 encoded__VIEWSTATE as an exfil field.
data.tools:
Metasploit Reverse HTTP Payloads
C2 Matrix

data.name: HTTPS as Exfil
data.description: This is pretty basic: the attackers use HTTPS. Lots and lots of malware uses this. For example, Meterpreter has used this technique for a long time. It can be used in conjunction with other stego techniques.
data.tools:
Metasploit Reverse HTTPS Payloads
SILENTTRINTY

data.name: DNS as C2
data.description: The attackers use DNS as a C2 channel.
data.tools: dnscat2

data.name: Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS)
data.description: The attackers use BITS, another protocol that is often ignored.
data.tools:
Leviathan
UBoatRAT

data.name: Gmail, Tumblr, Salesforce, Twitter as C2
data.description: The attackers route traffic through third-party services. Many services, like Gmail, are ignored completely by many security tools.
data.tools:
Gcat
Sneaky Creeper

data.name: Domain Fronting as C2
data.description: The attackers use Domain Fronting to bounce their traffic off of legitimate systems.
data.tools: Cobalt Strike

data.name: Phish
data.description: The attackers send a malicious email targeting users. Because users are super easy to attack. Feel free to add a narrative of a CEO getting phished. Or maybe the Help Desk!
data.tools:
modalishka
evilginx
GoPhish

data.name: Web Server Compromise
data.description: The attackers take over an external web server. They use it to pivot to your internal network.
data.tools:
Zed Attack Proxy
sqlmap
Burp Proxy

data.name: External Cloud Access
data.description: The attackers gain access to your cloud resources. They use this access to pivot.
data.tools:
SprayingToolkit
truffleHog
FireProx

data.name: Insider Threat
data.description: An internal, disgruntled user exfiltrates information from your network.
detection: DLP (Ha! Ha! Kidding. DLP never works.)
data.tools:
Being considered a Full-Time Expenditure (FTE)
Long Hours
Addiction

data.name: Password Spray
data.description: The attackers gain access to your internal network by spraying commonly used passwords (like SeasonYear) against your organization. An example would be a VPN.
data.tools:
SprayingToolkit
FireProx
Hydra
MailSniper
BruteLoops
MSOLSpray

data.name: Trusted Relationship
data.description: A trusted third party who has access to your network is compromised. The attackers use this to pivot to your internal resources.
data.tools: An unfortunate and unfounded trust in humanity and business partners who are complete strangers.

data.name: Social Engineering
data.description: The attackers use social engineering to trick a user into running malware.
data.tools:
Phone
A goal and a dream of evil
People trusting people

data.name: Bring Your Own (Exploited) Device
data.description: Your organization allows users to bring in their own devices. Or, another way to put it, they bring in their own exploited devices. The attackers use these devices to compromise your organization.
data.tools: The completely asinine belief that somehow allowing people to bring their own devices in is a worthy cost savings.

data.name: Exploitable External Service
data.description: An external service has a misconfiguration or a publicly available exploit. The attackers take advantage of this to attack and pivot to internal resources.
data.tools:
Metasploit
Failed Patching Process
Unauthorized System Stood Up by Employee

data.name: Credential Stuffing
data.description: The attackers take advantage of third-party breaches to identify and use IDs and passwords against your organization.
data.tools:
Burp Suite
Hydra
Users registering for services with their work email addresses.

data.name: Honeypots Deployed
data.description: The Defenders had honeypots on their network. The Incident Captain must reveal the Pivot and Escalate Card to the Defenders.
data.notes: Check out the Active Defense Harbinger Distribution (ADHD), it has lots and lots of cool tools. Also, take a look at canarytokens.org.

data.name: It Was a Pentest
data.description: Ha! Ha! Just kidding, you were never attacked! The CEO hired an external firm (BHIS?) to run an unannounced Red Team.
data.notes: This is almost always a bittersweet moment for companies. On the one hand, they are glad it wasn't the real thing. On the other... well, they were compromised. It's time to start working through how to prevent this from happening again.

data.name: Data Uploaded to Pastebin
data.description: Bummer, the attackers have posted internal sensitive data on Pastebin. Your customers are now informed of the attack by the media.
data.notes: It happens... a lot, but it's just pure evil. Time to bring in Upper Management and the Legal Team.

data.name: SIEM Analyst Returns From Splunk Training
data.description: (+2) Modifier for Log-Related Actions
data.notes: Training is awesome. You need to get some.

data.name: Take One Procedure Card Away
data.description: What it says on the tin. Take a Procedure Card away from the Defenders. Hey, sometimes things don't work. Honestly, does this surprise you?
data.notes: Sometimes procedures fail. Sometimes they're not followed correctly. Sometimes you can't find a procedure when you need it the most. Nobody's perfect. Sorry.

data.name: Give The Defenders a Random Procedure Card
data.description: For whatever reason, everyone forgot they had this procedure. It must be Monday.
data.notes: Look, it happens all the time. We forget what we have. Different teams, different tools, different offices. It's nice when we all pull together as a team.

data.name: Lead Handler Has a Baby, Takes FMLA Leave
data.description: Yeah, there's always one person who pretty much runs the whole IR process. That one essential person. Well, now it's time for the Incident Captain to silence that person.
data.notes: We have to continue to be able to work effectively without the one or two most advanced people on the team. All of the quiet people who were just passively listening and hoping to not get called on now need to step up. Now is your time. Shine!

data.name: Bobby the Intern Kills the System You are Reviewing
data.description: This. Happens. Far. Too. Often.
data.notes: No. Murder is never okay. Don't even think that.

data.name: Legal Takes Your Most Skilled Handler Into a Meeting to Explain the Incident
data.description: Who brought a lawyer to the party? There's always one person who pretty much runs the whole IR process. That one essential person. Well, the legal team took that person away for "Very Important Reasons."
data.notes: They may never come back... all of the quiet people who were just passively listening and hoping to not get called on now need to step up. Now is your time. Shine!

data.name: Internal Password Spray
data.description: The attackers start a password spray against the rest of the organization from a compromised system.
data.tools:
DomainPasswordSpray
BruteLoops
Kerbrute
Metasploit

data.name: Kerberoasting/ASREPRoasting
data.description: The attackers use a"feature" of service principal names (SPNs) to extract and crack service passwords,
data.tools:
GhostPack:
- Rubeus
Impacket:
- GetNPUsers.py
- GetUserSPNs.py
Hashcat for Cracking

data.name: Broadcast/Multicast Protocol Poisoning
data.description: For years, LANMAN was the worst thing in Windows. Then LLMNR said, "Stand Back and Hold My Beer!" Basically, LLMNR lets a host ask for name resolution from any system on the same network. The attackers perform Broadcast/Multicast protocol poisoning on your Active Directory Network.
data.tools:
mitm6 attacks DHCPv6
Responder attacks LLMNR, NBI-NS, WPAD, and mDNS.

data.name: Weaponizing Active Directory
data.description: The attackers map domain trust relationships, group policies, user/group privileges, and object access control lists (ACLs) in your Active Directory.
data.tools:
BloodHound
DeathStar
CrackMapExec

data.name: Credential Stuffing
data.description: Valid Active Directory credentials have been discovered on open shares and files within your environment. These are used by the attackers.
data.tools:
PowerSploit:
- Invoke-ShareFinder
- Invoke-FileFinder
- Find-InterestingFile
ADExplorer.exe
MailSniper
Snaffler
CrackMapExec

data.name: New Service Creation/Modification
data.description: The attackers create and load their malware using a new service or existing service modification.
data.tools:
Sysinternals PSEXEC services.msc
Impacket:
- psexec.py
Metasploit:
- psexec
- getsystem

data.name: Local Privilege Escalation
data.description: The attackers use a misconfiguration or vulnerability in local software to gain administrative access.
data.tools:
Meterpreter Post-Exploitation Scripts
DLLHijackTest
PowerSploit:
- PowerUp
GhostPack:
- SharpUp

data.name: Malicious Service
data.description: The attackers add a service that starts every time the system starts.
data.tools:
Meterpreter Persistence Modules
msconfig.exe
SILENTTRINITY
Sysinternals:
- autoruns.exe

data.name: DLL Attacks
data.description: The attackers hijack the order in which dynamic link libraries (DLLs) are loaded. This is usually done through insecure directory/file permissions.
data.tools:
DLLHijackTest
PowerSploit:
- PowerUp

data.name: Malicious Driver
data.description: The attackers load a malicious driver into the operating system.
data.tools:
Pasam
Wingbird
SeaDuke
ROCKBOOT
Alureon

data.name: New User Added
data.description: Easy, the attackers add a new user to the local computer.
data.tools:
Metasploit
Cobalt Strike

data.name: Application Shimming
data.description: The attackers use the Application Compatibility Toolkit to trick applications into not seeing the ports, directories, files, and services the attackers want to hide.
data.tools: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK)

data.name: Malicious Browser Plugins
data.description: The attackers install plugins in the browser. This can be used as part of C2 and persistence. The browser is the new endpoint.
data.tools: Grammarly is a Keylogger graniet/chromebackdoor

data.name: Logon Scripts
data.description: The attackers install a script that triggers when a user logs on.
data.tools: Meterpreter Persistence

data.name: Evil Firmware
data.description: The attackers update the firmware of network cards, video cards, and BIOS or UEFI... with Evil! All of these are very difficult to detect and very difficult to update.
detection: Prayers to an Engaged and Merciful God
data.tools:
Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit
BadBIOS (... maybe.)
Trickbot

data.name: Accessibility Features
data.description: The attackers hijack Accessibility Features like Sticky Keys and On-Screen Keyboard.
data.tools:
Bash Bunny - For examples
USB Rubber Ducky - For examples

data.name: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) Log Analysis
data.description: Yeah... good luck with this one. Are you logging the right things? Do you regularly emulate attack scenarios to see if you can detect them?
data.tools:
SOF-ELK
JPCert Tool Analysis

data.name: Server Analysis
data.description: The ability to baseline a system and verify that it is operating in anormal state. By the way, this is more than simply running Task Manager and looking for evil_backdoor.exe.
data.tools:
DeepBlueCLI
SANS Analysis Cheat Sheets

data.name: Firewall Log Review
data.description: Can your organization analyze and understand firewall logs? Do you regularly emulate attack scenarios and verify that your procedures work?
data.tools: SOF-ELK

data.name: Network Threat Hunting - Zeek/RITA Analysis
data.description: Does your organization capture and review network traffic? Good! Do you know how to parse and review it? Is that process documented? Or, do you just run Zeek/RITA/Security Onion/ELK because the cool kids are doing it?
data.tools:
Real Intelligence Threat Analytics (RITA)
Security Onion
AC-Hunter
Passer
espy

data.name: Cyber Deception
data.description: The attackers go after one of your deception technologies. This could be a word web bug, honey account, or a full honeypot.
data.tools:
CanaryTokens
HoneyBadger
Active Defense Harbinger Distribution (ADHD)
MITRE Engage

data.name: Endpoint Security Protection Analysis
data.description: We know, you have AV. Great! Do you actually get alerts and logs? Do you immediately review them? Or, do you simply turn it on and walk away while the network explodes like you're in a bad action movie?
data.tools: Check with your vendor, they miss you and always want to chat

data.name: User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA)
data.description: It's like logging, but it actually works. User and entity behavior analytics (UEBA) looks for multiple concurrent logons, impossible logons based on geography, unusual file access, password sprays, and more!
data.tools:
LogonTracer
DeepBlueCLI
OpenUBA

data.name: Endpoint Analysis
data.description: This is where the Defenders use their SANS IR Cheat Sheets to detect attacks on workstations. Time to bring in a local operator... and hope for the best.
data.tools:
DeepBlueCLI
Velociraptor
SANS IR Cheat Sheets

data.name: Isolation
data.description: Your network team is on their game. They can easily isolate infected systems to prevent further harm.
data.tools: Switch and Router Commands

data.name: Crisis Management
data.description: Your Legal and Management Teams have procedures for effectively and ethically notifying impacted victims of compromises.
data.tools: This almost never happens. But, a good notification strategy will really help deal with the political fallout.

data.name: Memory Analysis
data.description: The Defenders pull the memory from the suspect system and review it for possible malicious activity.
data.tools:
Volatility, to review the memory
Velociraptor, to dump the memory
